labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: Does the draft need a Private Key section?
issues.author: csosto-pk

comments.author: seanturner
bwesterb
comments.body:
There are some choices that can be made here. Let's discuss Dilithium2 as an example.

As proposed by the submission to NIST, a private key consists of

1. ρ a cryptographic seed for the lattice A;
2. K, a cryptographic seed;
3. s1, s2 the secret vectors;
4. tr = H(ρ || t1), where t1 is part of the public key and
5. t0 such that t0 + 2^d t1 = As1 + s2

During key generation, these are all computed from a single 32 byte seed ζ.

There are some trade-offs that could be made:

1. One could store only ζ and recompute the required values. This is very fast: it only adds 300,000 cycles to the 1,300,000 cycles for minting a signature on AVX2. This makes a lot of sense for applications where storage is at a premium: it would only need 32 bytes instead of 2,528B.
2. If storage is plentiful, then one could store the lattice A (16kB) in the private key as well for a small speed-bump.

I think standardising 1 as well would be worthwhile.

comments.author: mouse07410
comments.body: Since this draft is not about storing (or worse - passing around) private keys in an interoperable format, IMHO it does _not_ need to define Private key format.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: 100% agree it is _not needed_ but is there harm in including it? If we end up being unable to come to consensus on the options, then I would say it's okay to drop it. But, if we can, why not keep it.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: I think a standardised private key format is required. For instance: many private keys today are generated by _certbot_ (before it fetches a certificate from it from Let's Encrypt) and then read by some webserver. _certbot_ and the webserver need to agree on the private key format.

comments.author: tarcieri
comments.body:
I would agree it would be nice to have a single comprehensive document for both public and private keys and would also point to RFC8410 as an example.

Among other things RFC8410 included PKCS#8 v1 and v2 private key test vectors in their PEM encoding, which would be something nice to see in a similar RFC for ML-KEM / ML-DSA.

(Though I would hope you don't make the same mistake of including a nested inner `OCTET STRING` in the `privateKey` field, which is just needless complexity)

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: For posterity, the LAMPS [working group consensus](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/spasm/KPg3lbPeNms2H5PNDBt0iJByuE0/) is to standardise only the seed as portable private key. We'll add this to the draft.

comments.author: tarcieri
comments.body:
For ML-KEM, I think it might be worth considering using a KDF to expand a smaller seed (i.e. one that matches the security level, as opposed to a 64-byte one).

Some discussion about that on pqc-forum here: https://groups.google.com/a/list.nist.gov/g/pqc-forum/c/1r6FnG0coiM/m/I9_Jn5lJDQAJ

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: I agree that would be nice, and we [suggested it](https://groups.google.com/a/list.nist.gov/g/pqc-forum/c/5CT4NC_6zRI/m/lpifFrpWAwAJ) for the final version of ML-KEM. NIST didn't go for it. Now the problem is that we don't want the mess that some implementation support a 32 byte seed and others a 64 byte seed. With the 32 byte seed we don't have to think about MAL-BIND-X, but that security property has rather marginal applicability anyway. Not sure it's worth creating a mess with having two kinds of seeds.

comments.author: tarcieri
comments.body:
> Now the problem is that we don't want the mess that some implementation support a 32 byte seed and others a 64 byte seed.

Unambiguously supporting both is possible, but perhaps more pain than it's worth.

issues.title: Multiple algorithms within same draft
issues.author: jakemas
issues.body:
When constructing the draft for PQ signature algorithms for X.509, I envisioned the draft to encompass all chosen signature algorithms from NISTs PQC project (e.g., say both Dilithium and SPHINCS+ are selected, then the draft would include both algorithms). However Panos has given a few reasons to restrict each draft to a single algorithm type (e.g. say, just Dilithium), and have multiple drafts.

The same question can be asked for the KEM algorithms chosen, say NIST select 3 to be standardised, would we combine all algorithms in the same draft? or split them separately. Currently this draft names multiple candidates.

Some reasons for separating:
- There may exist vast differences in mathematical underpinning (say between a lattice and a code-based candidate) - this would be like seeing ECDSA and RSA in the same draft.
- Should any algorithm become revoked/deprecated the separation would more cleanly provide the means to reflect this in the drafts with potentially less confusion to the reader.
- More algorithms in a single draft may bloat the specific security considerations (that may significantly vary if based upon different underpinning).
- May allow separate drafts to move fast through the IETF process.

Just opening a dialogue for rebuttal/discussion.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body:
These are all really good points and to be honest I really do not have a super strong reason to keep them all in one I-D.  This is definitely something that we can raise to the WG when reviewing the I-D.

One the point about deprecating algorithms more easily: I sure hope that won't happen anytime soon.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: I hope it won't happen either, but it's not unlikely that some schemes will loose security due to advances in cryptanalysis. What I am sure of, is that we'll see new more performant signature schemes proposed in a few years.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: You have won me over to one alg per I-D. Helps that NIST just picked Kyber. Will get to modifying this I-D to reflect that in the text and in the name.

issues.title: Change name of I-D
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body: Since we've only got one KEM let's call it what it is.

issues.title: The WG migration plan
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body:
Fellow authors (and anybody else following along),

This I-D has been adopted by the LAMPS WG, see this [email](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/browse/spasm/).

I plan to transfer this repo the [LAMPS WG repo](https://github.com/lamps-wg/) and change the name of the repo to "nist-pqc-kem-kyber-certificates". My plan is to *only* merge #21 for the -00 WG version, because I want to make all the changes discussed, i.e., making the I-D Kyber specific, under the banner of the WG. With this approach we will also stop people saying "hey, we accepted a very different I-D than the one you submitted".

Starting next week, I'll submit PRs to make changes to the I-D that are intended to land in the -01 version of the WG version, i.e., the one named draft-ietf-lamps-nist-pqc-kem-kyber-certificates.

Cheers,
spt

issues.title: subjectPublicKey encoding
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body:
Currently, the I-D includes the following:

    * subjectPublicKey contains the byte stream of the public key.  The
      algorithms defined in this document always encode the public key
      as TODO pick format e.g., exact multiple of 8 bits?.

Is it correct to say that the public key is always encoded and exact multiple of 8 bits?

issues.title: Kyber->ML-KEM
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body:
At IETF 118, the WG was definitely in favor of changing the name to track NIST's name:
Module-Lattice-Based Key-Encapsulation Mechanism (ML-KEM).

issues.title: align AlgorithmIdentifier presenation with ML-DSA I-D
issues.author: seanturner

pulls.title: PK iteration 1
pulls.author: csosto-pk
pulls.body:
Minor changes 
- Remove Candidate 2 and made Candidate 1 to TBD1, just for simplicity reasons.
- Rephrased PQ Competition to PQ Project because NIST did not want to call it a Competion
- Added text about the uses of these certs that include PQ KEMs as public keys.

pulls.title: Updated references
pulls.author: csosto-pk
pulls.body: Fixed small nit, updated and added references.

pulls.title: Added author name

pulls.body: Added author

pulls.title: Updated Sec Considerations
pulls.author: csosto-pk
pulls.body: Added small Sec Considerations

pulls.title: Update name & titlle of I-D
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body: This is a bit wordy so I am open to shortening it. Thoughts?

comments.author: csosto-pk
comments.body: Sorry, I had forgotten about this one and I pushed the changes just now in a new file draft-ietf-lamps-kyber-certificates-00.md in https://github.com/seanturner/draft-turner-lamps-nist-pqc-kem-certificates/commit/38a922940b77d2c8f341fcad013c9e8e5ce89e07

Maybe get rid of "latest" here. 
I made this mistake in another draft of mine.

This title is OK but a little long. I am OK with it though. 

Another option is 
> Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure: Additional Algorithm Identifiers for Kyber Public Keys

which was used in recent https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8692

I am ok with either though.
I like the shorter title. Might drop "Additional" though ;)
ack

```suggestion
title: Internet X.509 Public Key Infrastructure: Algorithm Identifiers for Kyber Public Keys
```
Kyber Identifiers in X.509

```suggestion
docname: draft-ietf-lamps-nist-pqc-kem-kyber-certificates
```

pulls.title: Tightening Up Abstract
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body: Making the Abstract a little more crisp. Shortens the note as well because the WG agreed to do one I-D per algorithm, i.e., if any other KEMs are chosen they go in their own I-D.

comments.body: is <ins>a</ins>

```suggestion
Kyber is a key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM). This document specifies
```
Yep

pulls.title: Tightening Up Intro (1)
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body:
Cleaning up intro. Also adds references to Kyber in CMS and AUTHKEM as well as ASN.1 references.

I almost included that "Kyber is an IND-CCA2-secure key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM)", but figured we could into IND-CCA2 in the security considerations as few are going to have a clue about the significance of IND-CCA2.

NOTE: Also see #26, which is an alternative intro.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Seem to be leaning towards #26 after mods from @csosto-pk.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Closed in favor of #26.

```suggestion
    seriesinfo:
```

```suggestion
    seriesinfo:
```

```suggestion
  X680:
```

```suggestion
  X690:
```
Kyber doesn't allow you to pick the shared secret to encapsulate. Instead, perhaps: "[...] to generate and encapsulate [...]"

reviews.author: csosto-pk
reviews.body:
Changes look fine assuming the minor comments are addressed. 

I slightly like this one more, but I could live with the other intro as well.

comments.body: Remove "winning". "selected Kyber" sounds better.

pulls.title: Tightening Up Intro (2)
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body:
This takes a slightly different slant by:
- removing reference to NIST PQ Project - some might not care and implement it regardless
- pretty sure the Kyber OIDs are going in ASN.1 module  that will be referenced [here](https://csrc.nist.gov/Projects/Computer-Security-Objects-Register/algorithm-registration#Modules)
- We can be explicit about the applicability by putting it in a sub-section.

Note: Also see #25, which is an alternative intro.

comments.author: csosto-pk
comments.body: Personally I prefer the Tightening Up Intro (1) [PR #25](https://github.com/lamps-wg/kyber-certificates/pull/25) but I am fine with this one too assuming we address the two minor comments.

```suggestion
    seriesinfo:
```

```suggestion
    seriesinfo:
```

```suggestion
  X690:
```

```suggestion
  X680:
```

```suggestion
certificate extension; see {{Section 4.2.1.3 of RFC5280}}.
```

reviews.author: csosto-pk
reviews.body:
Looks fine. 

Just mention that Kyber was standardized in the NIST PQ project as explained in the relevant comment. 

And rephrase a bit that you generated and encapsulate a secret, it is not a secret the sender completely controls.

comments.body:
If you keep this intro, just mention the word NIST PQ standardization effort. The rest is fine. Something like 
> [...] key-encapasulation mechanism (KEM) standardized in the US NIST PQC Project {{PQCProj}}
Same as the other comment. Kyber doesn't allow you to pick the shared secret to encapsulate. Instead, perhaps: "[...] to generate and encapsulate [...]"

reviews.author: seanturner
reviews.body: I think this is a happy medium.

comments.body:
```suggestion
generate and encapsulate a shared secret used to derive a symmetric key used to
```

```suggestion
Kyber is a key-encapsulation mechanism (KEM) standardized by the US NIST
PQC Project {{PQCProj}}. This document specifies the use of the Kyber
algorithm at three security levels, Kyber512, Kyber768, and Kyber1024,
in X.509 public key certificates; see {{!RFC5280}}. Public and private
key encodings are also specified.
```

```suggestion
informative:
  PQCProj:
    target: https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/post-quantum-cryptography
    title: Post-Quantum Cryptography Project
    author:
      - org: National Institute of Standards and Technology
    date: 2016-12-20
```

nit: add a colon to start of list?
>This document specifies the use of the Kyber algorithm at three security levels: Kyber512, Kyber768, and Kyber1024,

```suggestion
algorithm at three security levels: Kyber512, Kyber768, and Kyber1024,
```

pulls.title: Updating template to match latest from MT
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body: Tweaking metadata to align with latest [template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/martinthomson/internet-draft-template/main/draft-todo-yourname-protocol.md). Should get rid of a build warning about not knowing the submissiontype.

pulls.title: Tweaks to Algorithm Identifiers section
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body:
Minor changes here:
* Since we are referring to the 2021 ASN.1 syntax in an early section we should just use it here.
* List the 3 Kyber identifiers.
* Made the last paragraph a note.

pulls.title: Adding PK ASN.1

pulls.body:
Added Kyber-* PK ASN.1.

Also deleted the Key Usage section because it's not clear we needed it - since it's algorithm and all the strengths use the same value.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: @jakemas I believe these are correct, but would like another set of eyes.

comments.author: jakemas
comments.body:
Taking a look now. Just a quick one on the private key encoding:
```
SEQUENCE (3 elem)
  INTEGER 0
  SEQUENCE (1 elem)
    OBJECT IDENTIFIER 1.3.6.1.4.1.44363.45.1234.1
  OCTET STRING (2404 byte) 04820960891865AEF10CB22387CAE735180B85D14C436F931790804047F7363715B2…
    OCTET STRING (2400 byte) 891865AEF10CB22387CAE735180B85D14C436F931790804047F7363715B2C1C430D3…
```
Why do we wrap the priv key in an additional OCTET STRING layer? (I know other algorithm such as ed25519 private keys are like this too, but is this an artefact of parameter sets that we don't need to carry over?) @bwesterb @seanturner 

Is it there for the optional addition of the public key inside the private key structure?

comments.author: jakemas
comments.body: Other than that, the Public key looks good to me.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
> Why do we wrap the priv key in an additional OCTET STRING layer?

This is how I interpreted:

> For the keys defined in this document, the private key is always an     
> opaque byte sequence. The ASN.1 type PqckemPrivateKey is defined in   
> this document to hold the byte sequence. Thus, when encoding a          
> OneAsymmetricKey object, the private key is wrapped in a         
> PqckemPrivateKey object and wrapped by the OCTET STRING of the         
> "privateKey" field.  

I would prefer to remove the wrapping as well.

@seanturner @csosto-pk

comments.author: jakemas
comments.body: Thanks, then I agree with your interpretation of the standard, and in that respect the private key is good with me. I think the bigger question is what do we want to do about this wrapping, is there a compelling argument for it? In the Dilithium spec I am currently not double wrapping like this, but I've noticed it done historically in many other specifications. Perhaps consistency..?

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: rfc8410 defining the Edwards primitives is pretty recent and does this. Why? I don't know.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body:
Honestly, I can't remember why there's an extra octet string wrapper in the private key. The only thing I can think of is in that looking at the definition of the pk-x25519 definition (from RFC 8410),

    pk-X25519 PUBLIC-KEY ::= {
        IDENTIFIER id-X25519
        -- KEY no ASN.1 wrapping --
        PARAMS ARE absent
        CERT-KEY-USAGE { keyAgreement }
        PRIVATE-KEY CurvePrivateKey
    }

, is that they didn't think they could define PRIVATE-KEY like this:

        PRIVATE-KEY PrivateKey

If we can verify that the ASN.1 will compile with latter definition, then I think we drop it unless somebody else can remind us why it happened that way.

On the public key, I think we encoded it correctly, but I want to make sure the text matches the example:

1) The text in -kyber and similarly in -dilithium includes the following:

    subjectPublicKey contains the byte stream of the
    public key. The algorithms defined in this document
    always encode the public key as TODO pick format
    e.g., exact multiple of 8 bits?

So is it always a multiple of 8 bits. I think so, but want to confirm.

2) The KEY line in the pk- definition includes:

    KEY Kyber-PublicKey

In 8410, it's:

    -- KEY no ASN.1 wrapping --

If we're not wrapping then shouldn't it be the latter (and match RFC 8410)?

3) In -dilithium, there is text about rho and t1 and how they are an OCTET STRING and then how that OCTET STRING is converted into the BIT STRING. Couple of questions:

3.1) Is similar text needed in -kyber?

3.2) I looked at the -dilithium example and am wondering if the two values rho and t1 are just concatenated together (i.e., the tag and length octets are omitted right?). The implication here is that you might not need to define *DilithiumPublicKey*.

comments.author: jakemas
comments.body:
> If we can verify that the ASN.1 will compile with latter definition, then I think we drop it unless somebody else can remind us why it happened that way.

Sounds good to me!


> On the public key, I think we encoded it correctly, but I want to make sure the text matches the example:
> 
> 1. The text in -kyber and similarly in -dilithium includes the following:
>    subjectPublicKey contains the byte stream of the
>    public key. The algorithms defined in this document
>    always encode the public key as TODO pick format
>    e.g., exact multiple of 8 bits?
> 
> So is it always a multiple of 8 bits. I think so, but want to confirm.
> 
> 2. The KEY line in the pk- definition includes:
>    KEY Kyber-PublicKey
> 
> In 8410, it's:
> 
> ```
> -- KEY no ASN.1 wrapping --
> ```
> 
> If we're not wrapping then shouldn't it be the latter (and match RFC 8410)?
> 
> 3. In -dilithium, there is text about rho and t1 and how they are an OCTET STRING and then how that OCTET STRING is converted into the BIT STRING. Couple of questions:
> 
> 3.1) Is similar text needed in -kyber?
> 
> 3.2) I looked at the -dilithium example and am wondering if the two values rho and t1 are just concatenated together (i.e., the tag and length octets are omitted right?). The implication here is that you might not need to define _DilithiumPublicKey_.

Right, the public key is just treated as one item (the concatenation of rho and t1). I added the detail about rho and t1 for informative purposes, to try and very briefly describe what a Dilithium public key is in more tangible terms - but I am not attempting to deconstruct the public key into these parts.

The text regarding the conversion from OCTET STRING to BIT STRING was added following from what RFC 5208 did:
“treat BIT STRING and OCTET STRING identically (doing sensible 0-bit-padding if BIT STRING is no multiple of 8)”. As in https://www.secg.org/sec1-v2.pdf section 2.3.1/2.3.2

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body:
Okay having refreshed my memory a bit about the extra wrapper .... From RFC 5958/5908

     privateKey is an OCTET STRING that contains the value of the
     private key.  The interpretation of the content is defined in the
     registration of the private-key algorithm.  For example, a DSA key
     is an INTEGER, an RSA key is represented as RSAPrivateKey as
     defined in [RFC3447], and an Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC) key
     is represented as ECPrivateKey as defined in RFC5915].

That means for RSA you'd stuff:

      RSAPrivateKey ::= SEQUENCE {
          version           Version,
          modulus           INTEGER,  -- n
          publicExponent    INTEGER,  -- e
          privateExponent   INTEGER,  -- d
          prime1            INTEGER,  -- p
          prime2            INTEGER,  -- q
          exponent1         INTEGER,  -- d mod (p-1)
          exponent2         INTEGER,  -- d mod (q-1)
          coefficient       INTEGER,  -- (inverse of q) mod p
          otherPrimeInfos   OtherPrimeInfos OPTIONAL
      }

For DSA, you stuff an INTEGER (from RFC 3279).

For EC, you stuff:

    ECPrivateKey ::= SEQUENCE {
         version        INTEGER { ecPrivkeyVer1(1) } (ecPrivkeyVer1),
         privateKey     OCTET STRING,
         parameters [0] ECParameters {{ NamedCurve }} OPTIONAL,
         publicKey  [1] BIT STRING OPTIONAL
       }

For X25519, X448, Ed25519, and Ed448 , you stuff:

   CurvePrivateKey ::= OCTET STRING

For Kyber we currently have:

    PqckemPrivateKey ::= OCTET STRING

So maybe we try this like we did for the public key:

   pk-kyber-* PUBLIC-KEY ::= {
       IDENTIFIER id-alg-kyber-*
       -- KEY no ASN.1 wrapping --
       PARAMS ARE absent
       CERT-KEY-USAGE
         { keyEncipherment }
       --- PRIVATE-KEY no ASN.1 wrapping -- }

We would also need to tweak the text in s7 that talks about PqckemPrivateKey to just say it's copied directly without any wrapper.

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: Removed wrapping and updated example on top.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: @jakemas PTAL

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: Note that this is round 3 Kyber. It's different from the draft ML-KEM. I don't think it's worthwhile to update to draft ML-KEM, as final ML-KEM probably differs from draft ML-KEM.

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: Ah I was working on a PR to swap out "Kyber" for "ML-KEM", but maybe we should hold off on doing that?

comments.author: seanturner
comments.body: At the LAMPS session @ IETF 118, I asked whether we should include the example certs and include the ML-KEM name change.  The WG wanted the examples and the name change with a strong warning that it's an example of the roundd 3 Kyber.

pulls.title: md: aside consistency
pulls.author: seanturner
pulls.body: Making the aside blocks consistent

comments.body:
```suggestion
\ [EDNOTE:
This document is not expected to be finalized before the NIST PQC
Project has standardized PQ algorithms. This specification will use
object identifiers for the new algorithms that are assigned by NIST,
and will use placeholders until these are released.
```
